event.doc_name: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

evidence.text: On October 3, 2023, President Biden nominated Plaintiff Hampton Dellinger to be Special Counsel of the Office of Special Counsel. The Senate confirmed Mr. Dellinger on February 27, 2024, and he was sworn in as Special Counsel on March 6, 2024. Mr. Dellinger’s five-year term expires in 2029.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Dellinger's nomination by President Biden on October 3, 2023, confirmed by the Senate on February 27, 2024, and sworn in as Special Counsel on March 6, 2024, with a five-year term expiring in 2029

evidence.text: On February 7, 2025, at 7:22 PM, Special Counsel Dellinger received an email from Sergio Gor, Assistant to the President and the Director of the White House Presidential Personnel Office, which stated in its entirety: 'On behalf of President Donald J. Trump, I am writing to inform you that your position as Special Counsel of the US Office of Special Counsel is terminated, effective immediately. Thank you for your service[.]'
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Termination email from Sergio Gor (Director of White House Presidential Personnel Office) to Dellinger on February 7, 2025, at 7:22 PM, stating position terminated effective immediately with no justification

evidence.text: The Office of Special Counsel is an independent agency of the United States... Congress in the CSRA provided that the Special Counsel 'may be removed by the President only for inefficiency, neglect of duty, or malfeasance in office.'
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: OSC's statutory role protecting federal whistleblowers under CSRA (1978) and Whistleblower Protection Act (1989), with Special Counsel removable only for cause

evidence.text: Over the preceding three weeks, an unprecedented number of federal employees with civil service protections have been terminated without cause. Senior career officials have been purged from the Federal Bureau of Investigations. Eighteen Inspectors General from across the federal government have been removed without the justification required by statute. And hundreds of federal employees have been locked out of their computer systems by the U.S. DOGE Service Temporary Organization.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Recent removal of 18 Inspectors General without statutory justification, purging of senior career officials from FBI, and hundreds of federal employees locked out of computer systems by US DOGE Service

args.reason: All checklist items (Factual_Basis_of_Case) are fully extracted with 4 distinct values from the fully visited Complaint document. No further document reading or checklist updates are needed.
